<keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/f3f46b67-c76b-49f2-bb90-aee0d72cafb6">PRICES</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/3e37158b-8428-4bd2-b966-47fc7bec502a">PRODUCER PRICE INDEX</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/11657fcc-7928-43e0-94b7-ffb3a0ee11f4">PRODUCTS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/29f5e72f-316c-4bd8-92bd-94cb62aff3c8">RETAIL OUTLETS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/df7c727f-9d7a-42f2-8729-768a4b84dd84">RETAIL PRICE INDEX</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/6dae1f49-a0f0-4e55-adc5-9fa554734c7d">SHOPPING AREAS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/23eb1c02-2521-4805-a6eb-7bdbb17403d2">SHOPS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/4a821930-5499-4bb4-b058-ab0ae3c8746b">UNITED KINGDOM</keyword>         <topcClas>Economic conditions and indicators - Economics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Trade, industry and markets - Industry and management</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Prices Survey Microdata</i> include the underlying price data used by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) to produce the Consumer Prices Index (CPI), the Retail Prices Index (RPI) and associated price indices.  The CPI has become the main domestic measure of inflation for macroeconomic purposes in the UK. Since December 2003 it has been used for the inflation target that the Bank of England is required to achieve. The RPI is the most long-standing measure of inflation in the UK, and its uses have included the indexation of pensions, state benefits and index-linked gilts.  The study also includes the data underlying the Producer Prices Index.<br> <br> There are four levels of sampling for local price collection: locations/shopping areas; outlets/shops within locations; representative items/goods and services; and products and varieties (price quotes).<br> <br> There are two basic price collection methods: local and central.  Local collection is used for most items; prices are obtained from outlets in about 150 locations around the country. Some 110,000 quotations are obtained by this method. Normally, collectors must visit the outlet, but prices for some items may be collected by telephone.  Central collection is used for items where all the prices can be collected centrally by the ONS with no field work. These prices can be further sub-divided into two categories, depending on their subsequent use: 1) central shops, where the prices are combined with prices obtained locally, and 2) central items, where the prices are used on their own to construct centrally calculated indices.  There are about 130 items for which the prices are collected centrally.<br> <br> The retail price data include the locations containing the shopping outlets from which the price quotes were obtained.  These locations are intended to be broadly representative of a central shopping area and the areas where the local shopping population tend to live.  The data also include the regions in which those shopping areas are located.<br> <br> <i>Linking to other business studies</i><br> The producer prices data contain Inter-Departmental Business Register (IDBR) reference numbers. These are anonymous but unique reference numbers assigned to business organisations. Their inclusion allows researchers to combine different business survey sources together. Researchers may consider applying for other business data to assist their research.<br> <br> The third edition (October 2014) includes Producer Prices Index files for 1996-2013, locally collected retail prices data for 2013, item index files for 1996-first quarter 2014, and updates to a number of backdata files.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The <i>Prices Survey Microdata</i> include both retail and producer prices.  The retail data include the following files:<ul><li>'backdata' or background information files</li><li>locally collected items data files</li><li>centrally collected items and indices files</li></ul>The 'backdata' background information files include:<ul><li>Classification of Individual Consumption by Purpose (COICOP) descriptions and identification codes</li><li>descriptions and identification codes for each item (goods and services)</li><li>location descriptions and identification codes (and the region of the UK)</li><li>shop codes for each item and location</li></ul>The pre-2007 data also include postcodes for the shops.<br> <br> The producer prices files span from 1998 to 2007 and include:<ul><li>item and index number codes</li><li>Inter-Departmental Business Register Reporting Unit reference numbers, allowing the data to be matched to other ONS business survey data</li><li>index descriptions</li><li>prices for each item/index number</li></ul>Additional producer prices files spanning January 1996 to August 2013 provide only the Producer Prices Indices.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1996-01-01T00:00:00Z">January 1996</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2014-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2014</timePrd>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Institutions/organisations</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Retail prices: representative shopping areas, shopping outlets, items and products in the UK; Producer prices: products and businesses sampled by the <i>Products of the European Community</i> (Prodcom) survey.</universe>         <dataKind>Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Office for National Statistics</dataCollector>         <sampProc>See documentation for details</sampProc>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Telephone interview; Postal survey; Transcription of existing materials</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Secure data</specPerm>         <restrctn>Registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. Controlled data requirements and conditions also apply. Further information is available from <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/accesssecurelab.aspx'>Access to the Secure Lab</a>. In addition, the Service is required to request explicit permission from the data owner prior to providing the researcher with access to the data.<br> Available to UK HE/FE applicants only. <p>Please note:<br>Since these data are more sensitive and/or pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence or under a Special Licence, they are not available for download but may be accessed through Secure Access. Access requires accreditation by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher, completion of face-to-face training, and agreement to the Secure Access's <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176858/ukda140_sds_sdsagreement_public.pdf'>User Agreement</a> and <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176861/UKDA142_SDS_SecurityBreaches_public.pdf'>Breaches Penalties Policy</a>. This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. Applications are screened by the UK Data Archive and the Office for National Statistics, and access is only granted to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the data. Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'> Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
